title: An Elevator Pitch in Distribution?
excerpt: Before implementing NDC or a new PSS, can you answer the fundamental question: do you know what your customers want? Ann Cederhall challenges the industry.
author: Retailaer
content:
From our reading list: Ann Cederhall asks the question we wish more airlines would answer before embarking on major technology initiatives: "Why?" Too often, NDC and retail become buzzwords divorced from actual strategy. This piece is a must-read for anyone about to sign a vendor contract.

The Problem with "We Must Do NDC"

Ann critiques the airline industry's tendency to pursue NDC, retail strategies, and modern PSS systems without clear strategic reasoning. "We must do NDC" has become an industry mantra lacking substance. As she puts it: "NDC is just a standard and is not going to help you to Retail" without accompanying strategic transformation.

The First Question

Before any technology decision, airlines must ask: "Do you know what your customers want?"

Key Strategic Questions

On Content Strategy

  • Customers want added value: cancellation flexibility, change policies
  • Dynamic bundling with discounts appeals to passengers
  • Ancillary products (eSIMs, food, electronic bag tags) enhance travel
  • Travelers expect recognition across multi-leg journeys despite PNR splits

On Customer Experience

  • Communicate through preferred customer channels
  • Implement efficient IROP systems
  • Enable quick refunds
  • Offer flights on partner airlines

On Distribution Cost Reduction

  • Modernize outdated financial models
  • Grow direct sales through incentives
  • Address rising PSS costs and plan alternatives

Ann's advice: "Talk to many different people" and develop substantive answers to "Why NDC," "Why Retail," and "Why replace the PSS?" before implementing these initiatives. Strategic clarity precedes technological adoption.
